docs.title: French PR Accelerator (Canada) — Content-First Phase 1
docs.text:
Goal: go from scratch to a PR-relevant French level, optimized for TEF Canada / TCF Canada and NCLC 7 (a common target for Express Entry strategies).

This repo is a learning plan + free resources.

docs.title: Why NCLC 7?
docs.text:
For Express Entry, strong French can: - qualify you for French-language proficiency draws - add CRS bonus points (commonly +25 or +50 depending on English level)

Start here: - IRCC language tests: https://www.canada.ca/en/immigration-refugees-citizenship/services/immigrate-canada/express-entry/documents/language-test.html - CRS additional points (French): https://www.canada.ca/en/immigration-refugees-citizenship/services/immigrate-canada/express-entry/check-score/crs-criteria.html

docs.title: Phase 1 (finish in ≤ 2 days)
docs.text: By the end of Phase 1 you will have: - A clear target score and test choice (TEF vs TCF) - A daily routine + weekly ladder (A0 → B2/NCLC7) - A bank of speaking + writing templates for exam-style tasks - A curated list of free resources (TV5MONDE, RFI, YouTube)

docs.title: Do this first
docs.text:
1. docs/00-START-TODAY-2H.md
  2. docs/01-PR-TARGETS-TEF-TCF.md
  3. Start the daily routine in docs/08-TRACKER-8-WEEKS.md

docs.title: Daily routine (2 hours/day, “accelerated but sustainable”)
docs.text:
20 min — spaced repetition vocab (Anki or any SRS) 20 min — pronunciation drills (record yourself) 40 min — input (easy listening/reading with transcript) 40 min — output (speaking/writing using templates)

If you can do 3 hours/day, add: - +30 min “exam timed practice” - +30 min conversation practice

docs.title: Week-by-week ladder (typical path to NCLC 7)
docs.text:
Weeks 1–2 (A0→A1/A2): survival French + core grammar + pronunciation Weeks 3–4 (A2): high-frequency verbs, everyday topics, short writing Weeks 5–6 (B1): longer listening + structured speaking + emails/letters Weeks 7–8 (B1→B2): debate/argumentation + timed exam tasks Weeks 9–10 (B2 polish): full mocks + feedback loop

Reality check: “from zero to NCLC7” often takes longer than 8 weeks. This plan is “accelerated” by focusing on exam-aligned skills early.

docs.title: Free core resources (bookmark)
docs.text:
Structured exercises - TV5MONDE (A1→B2): https://apprendre.tv5monde.com/fr - RFI Français Facile (A1→B2): https://francaisfacile.rfi.fr/fr/exercices/

YouTube (high value) - innerFrench: https://www.youtube.com/innerFrench - Français Authentique: https://www.youtube.com/user/francaisauthentique - Learn French With Alexa: https://www.youtube.com/user/learnfrenchwithalexa - Easy French: https://www.youtube.com/easyfrench

Grammar reference - Lawless French lessons by level: https://www.lawlessfrench.com/faq/lessons-by-level/

docs.title: Spanish advantage
docs.text: Spanish helps a lot (cognates, verb concepts, gender), but watch false friends. See: docs/02-SPANISH-BRIDGE.md

docs.title: Not immigration advice
docs.text: Immigration rules change. Always verify with IRCC and your program requirements.

docs.title: Start Today (2 hours) — Zero to Momentum
0) Setup (10 min)
docs.text:
• Create a notebook or a notes file called: FR-PR-Log
  • Install an SRS (recommended): Anki (ask Yashine about this first if you are unsure)
  • Pick a dictionary you like (WordReference works well): https://www.wordreference.com/

docs.title: 1) Choose your PR language goal (10 min)
docs.text:
Target for “PR-optimized French”: - NCLC 7 in all 4 skills (Listening, Reading, Writing, Speaking)

Read later: 01-PR-TARGETS-TEF-TCF.md

docs.title: 2) Pronunciation “must-fix early” (20 min)
docs.text:
Do these now (listen + repeat + record yourself): - French U vs OU (Spanish speakers often collapse them) - French R (throaty) vs Spanish rolled R - Nasal vowels: an/en, on, in - Silent endings + liaison basics

Use: - Learn French With Alexa (search within channel): https://www.youtube.com/user/learnfrenchwithalexa

docs.title: 3) First input session (30 min)
docs.text:
Choose ONE: - TV5MONDE A1 exercises: https://apprendre.tv5monde.com/fr/exercices/a1-debutant - RFI easy exercises: https://francaisfacile.rfi.fr/fr/exercices/

Rule: always prefer content with audio + transcript.

docs.title: Speaking (15 min)
docs.text: Record yourself answering: 1. Je me présente (name, work, studies, where you live, goal in Canada) 2. Pourquoi le Canada ? 3. Décrivez votre journée type.

docs.title: Writing (15 min)
docs.text:
Write 8–10 lines: - “Pourquoi je veux améliorer mon français pour le Canada.”

Keep it simple. Accuracy > complexity.

docs.title: 5) Micro-vocab starter (20 min)
docs.text: Create 25 flashcards (FR → ES/EN) from today’s content. Must include: - 5 verbs (être, avoir, aller, faire, pouvoir) - 5 connectors (et, mais, parce que, donc, aussi) - 5 “Canada life” words (logement, travail, rendez-vous, permis, assurance) - 10 personal words you actually need

docs.title: PR Targets + TEF Canada vs TCF Canada (what to aim for)
1) What PR usually wants (language-wise)
docs.text:
For many PR paths (especially Express Entry), IRCC evaluates language via an approved test. French tests accepted for Express Entry include: - TEF Canada - TCF Canada

IRCC page: https://www.canada.ca/en/immigration-refugees-citizenship/services/immigrate-canada/express-entry/documents/language-test.html

Validity: results are typically valid 2 years (verify on IRCC).

docs.title: 2) Why people target NCLC 7
docs.text:
NCLC 7 in all 4 skills is a common threshold for: - French-category strategies - CRS bonus points (often +25 or +50 depending on English)

CRS details: https://www.canada.ca/en/immigration-refugees-citizenship/services/immigrate-canada/express-entry/check-score/crs-criteria.html

docs.title: 3) TCF Canada format (high level)
docs.text:
TCF Canada includes 4 mandatory components: - Listening - Reading - Writing - Speaking

Official info: https://www.france-education-international.fr/en/test/tcf-canada?langue=en

docs.title: 4) Quick “score targets” to hit NCLC 7
docs.text: Always confirm with the latest official equivalency tables.

docs.title: TEF Canada (NCLC 7 target)
docs.text: Use IRCC equivalency tables: https://www.canada.ca/en/immigration-refugees-citizenship/services/study-canada/work/after-graduation/eligibility/language-results.html

docs.title: TCF Canada (NCLC 7 target)
docs.text: Use IRCC equivalency tables (example page): https://www.canada.ca/en/immigration-refugees-citizenship/services/immigrate-canada/rural-franco-pilots/franco-immigration/eligibility/language-test.html

docs.title: 5) Which test should you pick?
docs.text:
Pick the one with: - More test dates near you - A format you prefer (your strengths) - Better prep resources available to you

Rule of thumb: - If you like structured tasks and “exam technique”, either works. - If you want the most predictable prep path: choose the one you can book sooner + find mock tests for.

docs.title: Fast wins (Spanish helps)
docs.text:
1. Cognates (many shared Latin roots)
  2. important / importante
  3. nation / nación
  4. possible / posible
  5. Verb mindset (conjugations exist in both languages)
  6. Gender (often same, not always)

docs.title: Biggest traps (false friends)
docs.text:
• actuellement = "currently" (NOT "actualmente" meaning "actually" in English)
  • assister à = "to attend" (NOT "assistir" = help)
  • sensible = "sensitive" (NOT "sensato")
  • librairie = bookstore (NOT "library" = bibliothèque)
  • éventuellement = possibly (NOT "eventualmente" same-ish but watch usage)

docs.title: Pronunciation differences to fix early
docs.text:
• French u (tu) ≠ Spanish u
  • French r is guttural
  • Nasal vowels: en/an, on, in
  • Final consonants often silent (parle, petits, vous parlez)

docs.title: Grammar differences (high yield)
docs.text:
• French uses articles more consistently
  • Negation: ne ... pas (spoken French often drops ne)
  • Object pronouns positioning: je le vois / je vais le faire

docs.title: Study hack
docs.text: When you learn a new French word: - write the Spanish cognate if it exists - mark it (FF) if it might be a false friend

docs.title: The “Top 6” that matter most for intelligibility
docs.text:
1) u vs ou - tu / tout - rue / roue

2) French R (throat) - Paris, travail, vraiment

3) Nasal vowels - an/en: sans, français - on: bon, Ontario - in: demain, immigrant

4) Silent endings - parler (par-lé), petit (pə-ti), beaucoup (bo-koo)

5) Liaison (basic) - les amis (lé-za-mi) - un ami (un-na-mi)

6) Rhythm French is more “even” syllable timing than Spanish.

docs.title: Practice (10 minutes/day)
docs.text:
• Shadow 1 short clip (repeat with same rhythm)
  • Record yourself (phone) and listen back

docs.title: Free YouTube help
docs.text:
• Learn French With Alexa: https://www.youtube.com/user/learnfrenchwithalexa
  • Easy French (listen to real street French + subtitles): https://www.youtube.com/easyfrench

docs.title: Minimal pairs list (make flashcards)
docs.text:
• tu / tout
  • rue / roue
  • beau / bon
  • mais / mes
  • peut / peu
  • dessus / dessous

docs.title: Core Grammar Ladder (A0 → B2) — only what moves the needle
A0–A1 (Weeks 1–2): survival structure
docs.text:
• Pronouns: je/tu/il/elle/nous/vous/ils/elles
  • Present tense: être, avoir, aller, faire + regular -er
  • Negation: ne...pas (and spoken drop of "ne")
  • Questions: est-ce que / inversion (basic) / intonation
  • Articles: un/une/des, le/la/les, du/de la/des

Use: - Lawless French by level: https://www.lawlessfrench.com/faq/lessons-by-level/

docs.title: A2 (Weeks 3–4): control
docs.text:
• Passé composé (avoir/être) + agreement basics
  • Futur proche (aller + infinitive)
  • Pronouns: le/la/les, lui/leur, y, en (basics)
  • Comparatives: plus/moins/aussi ... que

docs.title: B1 (Weeks 5–6): fluency structure
docs.text:
• Imparfait vs passé composé
  • Relative pronouns: qui/que/où (core)
  • Conditionnel (polite requests + plans)
  • Subjunctive: only the “must know” triggers (il faut que, je veux que)

docs.title: B2 (Weeks 7–8+): argumentation
docs.text:
• Connectors: cependant, en revanche, puisque, donc, par conséquent
  • Hypotheses: si + tenses (realistic patterns)
  • Opinion frameworks: à mon avis, il me semble que, je suis convaincu(e) que

docs.title: Rule
docs.text: Do grammar to SUPPORT output (speaking/writing). Don’t “collect rules”.

docs.title: Input Ladder (A0 → B2): listen/read your way up
A0–A1: super-supported input
docs.text:
• TV5MONDE A1: https://apprendre.tv5monde.com/fr/exercices/a1-debutant

Goal: - 15 min/day + write 5 sentences you understood.

docs.title: A2: controlled authentic input
docs.text:
• TV5MONDE A2: https://apprendre.tv5monde.com/fr/exercices/a2-elementaire
  • RFI exercises (all levels): https://francaisfacile.rfi.fr/fr/exercices/

Goal: - 1 short audio/day + transcript + 10 new words.

docs.title: B1: real content, slower
docs.text:
• innerFrench (excellent bridge to real French): https://www.youtube.com/innerFrench
  • RFI “Journal en français facile” (with transcript): https://francaisfacile.rfi.fr/fr/podcasts/journal-en-fran%C3%A7ais-facile/

Goal: - 20–30 min/day + 1 paragraph summary.

docs.title: B2: faster, wider topics
docs.text:
• RFI B2 exercises: https://francaisfacile.rfi.fr/fr/exercices/b2/
  • Easy French (street interviews): https://www.youtube.com/easyfrench

Goal: - summarize + react (opinion) out loud for 2 minutes.

docs.title: The golden rule
docs.text: If you understand < 70%, go easier. Volume beats suffering.

docs.title: Speaking: universal 60-second structure
docs.text: 1) Answer clearly (1 sentence) 2) Give 2 reasons 3) Give 1 example 4) Conclude (so what / recommendation)

docs.title: Useful connectors
docs.text:
• d’abord, ensuite, enfin
  • parce que / puisque
  • donc / par conséquent
  • en revanche / cependant
  • par exemple

docs.title: Speaking: argumentation template (B2 / NCLC7-ish)
docs.text: À mon avis, , principalement pour deux raisons. D’abord, . Ensuite, . Par exemple, . En conclusion, je pense que ___.

docs.title: Writing: “formal email” template
docs.text:
Objet : ___

Bonjour Madame/Monsieur,

Je vous écris concernant . Je souhaiterais ___ parce que .

Serait-il possible de ___ ? Je vous remercie par avance de votre aide.

Cordialement, Prénom Nom

docs.title: Writing: opinion paragraph template
docs.text: Je pense que . Premièrement, . Deuxièmement, . Toutefois, . En conclusion, ___.

docs.title: Daily output drill (20 min)
docs.text:
• 10 min speaking (record)
  • 10 min writing (8–10 lines) Then correct ONE thing only (verb tense OR agreement OR connectors).

docs.title: Canada Topics (PR-relevant) + “Interview-style” prompts
docs.text: Even when PR uses test scores, you still want French for life + confidence.

docs.title: Core topics to master (vocab + speaking)
docs.text: 1) Work & skills (poste, expérience, responsabilités, objectifs) 2) Housing (logement, bail, coloc, quartier, loyer) 3) Healthcare (rendez-vous, assurance, clinique, pharmacie) 4) Banking (compte, carte, virement, facture) 5) Transportation (permis, trajet, abonnement, horaires) 6) Education (diplôme, formation, université) 7) Government/admin (formulaire, document, délai, statut)

docs.title: Practice questions (record 2 min each)
docs.text:
• Présentez-vous.
  • Pourquoi le Canada ? Pourquoi apprendre le français ?
  • Décrivez votre travail / vos études.
  • Parlez d’un défi que vous avez surmonté.
  • Donnez votre opinion sur le télétravail / l’immigration / l’environnement.
  • Expliquez une procédure (ex: prendre un rendez-vous médical).

docs.title: Weekly “real-life task”
docs.text:
• Call roleplay: make an appointment, ask for info, negotiate a schedule
  • Write: a polite email requesting information about an application

docs.title: Daily checklist (2 hours)
docs.text:
• [ ] 20 min SRS vocab
  • [ ] 20 min pronunciation (record yourself)
  • [ ] 40 min input + transcript
  • [ ] 40 min output (speaking + writing)

docs.title: Week 1
docs.text:
• [ ] Can introduce yourself (60s)
  • [ ] Present tense core verbs
  • [ ] 200–300 words active

docs.title: Week 2
docs.text:
• [ ] Basic questions + negation
  • [ ] 2-minute easy conversation
  • [ ] 400–600 words active

docs.title: Week 3–4 (A2)
docs.text:
• [ ] passé composé basics
  • [ ] write a simple email (10–12 lines)
  • [ ] 800–1200 words active

docs.title: Week 5–6 (B1)
docs.text:
• [ ] summarize a short audio
  • [ ] 3-minute structured speaking
  • [ ] 2 timed writings/week

docs.title: Week 7–8 (B2 push)
docs.text:
• [ ] argumentation speaking (pros/cons)
  • [ ] connectors + nuance
  • [ ] 1 full mock/week (timed)
